metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State of Rajasthan & Dharti Dan Shramik Theka Sahkari Samiti Ltd.

facts.text: Auction held on January 21, 1964 for royalty collection contract on building stones; appellant offered highest bid of Rs. 42,200; respondent No. 2 bid Rs. 33,000 and stopped.
Appellant did not deposit 25% of bid amount as security immediately after auction completion as required by r. 36(7) of Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1959.
Respondent No. 2, a co-operative society of laborers working in the mines, applied on March 5, 1964 for the contract citing Government policy preference for co-operatives.
State Government (respondent No. 1) granted royalty collection contract to respondent No. 2 by order dated April 1, 1964.
Appellant held royalty collection contract for 1963-64 with security deposit of Rs. 9,250.
On February 12, 1964, appellant applied to Mining Engineer, Jaipur, to adjust Rs. 9,250 security from previous contract and deposited Rs. 1,300; no reply received.
Previous contract period ends March 31; security refundable only after termination per Form of Agreement para 2 and 6.
Government policy to encourage co-operative societies for mining work per letter dated February 14, 1962 from Director of Mines and Geology.
Rajasthan High Court dismissed appellant's writ petition under Art. 226 on August 5, 1964; certificate granted for appeal.
Contract for 1964-65 nearing end at time of Supreme Court hearing.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Government is bound to confirm and grant the royalty collection contract to the highest bidder at auction or has discretion to prefer another bidder like a co-operative society under the rules.
Whether appellant's failure to deposit 25% security immediately forfeits its claim and whether adjustment of previous security was permissible.

petitioner_arguments.text: Government had merely to confirm the highest bid at auction by formality and was not competent to grant contract to lower bidder.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 36(5) and (7) of Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1959

petitioner_arguments.text: Practice of adjusting previous security deposits towards new contract security.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant failed to deposit 25% security immediately, losing any claim to contract.
Government has discretion not to confirm highest bid; r.59 allows relaxation for mineral development; policy prefers co-operative societies of laborers.
Adjustment of previous security not possible as prior contract ongoing till March 31.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant admitted non-deposit of 25% security, losing claim to contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: He therefore lost whatever claim he could have had for the final acceptance of his bid by Government.

court_reasoning.text: No provision binds Government to accept highest bid; bid not accepted unless confirmed; discretion exists.
court_reasoning.key_observation: A bid is not regarded as accepted unless confirmed by Government.

court_reasoning.text: R.59 allows relaxation of rules in interest of mineral development; policy justifies preferring co-operative of laborers whose benefit improves their conditions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The view taken by the Government in preferring respondent No. 2... cannot be said to be arbitrary or without any justification.

court_reasoning.text: Request for security adjustment not acceptable as previous security tied till contract end.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The request made in this letter could not possibly be accepted.

court_reasoning.text: Contract nearing end; undesirable to interfere even if contentions accepted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Another consideration... is that the contract... is shortly to come to an end and it would not be desirable... to interfere.

holdings.text: Government competent to grant contract to respondent No. 2, not bound to accept highest bid though usually does.
Appellant lost claim due to non-deposit of security; no valid adjustment of prior security.

precedents_cited.relevance: Reference to decision of this Court on not interfering with nearing-end contracts

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition seeking certiorari

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs auction, confirmation of bids, security deposit, and relaxation of rules for mineral development

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld; Government action in granting contract to respondent No. 2 validated as within discretion and policy.

key_quotes.text: "A bid is not regarded as accepted unless confirmed by Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes Government's discretion over highest bid

key_quotes.text: "The view taken by the Government in preferring respondent No. 2 to the appellant... cannot be said to be arbitrary or without any justification."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "He therefore lost whatever claim he could have had for the final acceptance of his bid by Government"
key_quotes.speaker: court
